awd_titl_txt: Probing catalyst-support interactions via experiment and theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Industrial catalysts often use precious metal nanoparticles on supporting surfaces to speed up a wide range of chemical reactions that are important in the chemical industry. Carbon-based materials that contains small amounts of nitrogen represent a class of materials for catalyst supports that offer an opportunity to improve the performance of current nanoparticle catalysts. Scientists do not yet  understand the fundamental interactions between the nanoparticle catalysts and these nitrogen-doped carbon supports. In this project, the research groups of Dr. Svitlana Pylypenko and Dr. Shubham Vyas of the Colorado School of Mines are using both targeted experiments and chemical computations to improve the interaction between nanoparticle catalysts and these nitrogen-doped carbon supports. Their results may produce less expensive and more earth-abundant catalysts while improving the yield of the desired product (no by-products). Drs. Pylypenko and Vyas are engaged in a multi-level outreach and educational program that involves K-12 students and teachers, as well as undergraduate and graduate researchers. Their recent developments blending experimental and computational approaches are discussed during a distinctive summer field session at the Colorado School of Mines. The insights gained by this research may advance the improve the performance of a wide range of catalytic applications that are vital to the chemical industry and domestic economy.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Drs. Pylypenko and Vyas are developing a fundamental understanding of catalyst-support interactions by investigating nanoparticle catalysts supported on nitrogen-doped carbons. Despite abundant reports of the advantageous impact of nitrogen functional groups on catalyst nucleation, stability, and, in some instances, catalytic activity, the underlying phenomena associated with catalyst-support interactions for these systems has not yet been elucidated - mainly due to the overall complexity of the system.  The team is using a synergistic approach that includes electronic structure calculations, controlled synthesis with targeted composition and morphology, and advanced ex situ and in situ characterization to decrease the cost of metal catalysts, reduce national dependence on precious metals, and lower the environmental impact associated with mining and processing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Functionalized carbon nanostructures have attracted significant interest for a myriad of catalytic reactions in energy applications.  The fundamental understanding of these materials is limited due to the challenges in identifying chemical speciation and distribution of different functionalities within a carbon support and relating them to performance. The objective of the project was to conduct a systematic investigation of the parameter space associated with carbon supports functionalized with nitrogen dopants and their effect on catalyst-support interactions using synergistic computational and experimental efforts. We have synthesized and characterized a carefully selected series of N-doped carbons, as well as N-doped carbons functionalized with metal.  Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were instrumental in verifying the morphology of the materials, 2D spatial distribution of nitrogen heteroatoms, and the chemical distribution of nitrogen functionalities. Variable energy XPS was used to demonstrate that certain nitrogen functionalities were more surface enriched than others. Opportunities and challenges of 3D characterization of N-doped carbon materials with atom probe tomography (APT) were considered and included both sample preparation and analysis of data. Next, we have investigated catalyst-support interactions as a function of electronic structure of metal by varying valence shell electrons and location of the valence shell and have studied the effect of functionality of nitrogen groups and their quantity on nucleation and stability of metal. Specifically, we computationally examined location of metal adsorption and the electronic structure of metals for a series of 12 transition metals located in groups 8-11 and periods 4-6 over various graphene models with graphitic and pyridinic nitrogen defects. Nitrogen was shown to improve the metal-support interactions promoting electronic rearrangements that increased adsorption, and trends between metals from different groups were identified. Down selected systems were investigated experimentally with STEM-EDS confirming enhanced interactions demonstrating that nature of the defect influences the metal-support interactions. Finally, through high throughput machine-learning-based imaging analysis paired with identical location microscopy we gained mechanistic insights into effects of N functionalities onto the dispersion and stability of externally grown metal nanoparticles, using Pt nanoparticles as a model system. The computational and experimental framework established in this project can be expanded to other dopants and metals to further study catalyst-support interactions for a variety of catalytic applications. Graduate students who worked on this project successfully completed their Ph.D.  degrees. Several undergraduate students obtained training under this project, and some went onto pursue graduate studies. Most of undergraduate students exposed to research under this project came from underrepresented groups.  The results of this work have been disseminated through publications and participation in scientific conferences. PIs contributed to the training of high school teachers through involvement in the Science Educators Workshop (SEW), a two-day workshop for high school science teachers offered annually during the AVS International Symposium and Exhibition, and education of K-5 students through the Summer Camp for Dyslexic Kids. PI also served as the faculty adviser of the Mines AVS student chapter, which allows local students to further their education, professional development and outreach efforts through various activities conducted throughout the year.
